title: Couple learn they are actually siblings after dating for months
text:
"He opened it on Christmas Eve, a huge smile on his face - things got weird after that."

More people are taking home DNA tests to learn about their background. For some, the results can be not only unexpected, but can radically change their lives. WSJ’s Amy Dockser Marcus explains. Photo illustration: Laura Kammermann/WSJ

As soon as *Stacey arrived to get her DNA results interpreted, she saw a flicker of confusion across the woman’s face.

The American woman tried to stay calm – convincing herself that she had imagined the baffled expression.

But Stacey was unable to shake the feeling of unease. After all, she is adopted and had no idea what secrets her DNA might be hiding about her biological family.

But it’s vry safe to say that she never would have expected what happened next.

“'It looks like I’ve found your birth mum,' the woman said. 'But…,' she continued. 'It looks like the same person is coming up for your boyfriend',” Stacey first wrote on Love What Matters.

“I couldn’t quite process what she was trying to tell me. Me. Him. Boyfriend? Same mother? What. That makes us… what? No. NO! ABSOLUTELY NOT. This can’t be true. Oh, but it was.”

"Me. Him. Boyfriend? Same mother? What. That makes us…what?" Source: iStock

Nobody knew the truth

Stacey had been adopted from birth by a couple who loved her as their own.

Although they were open about the fact she was adopted – Stacey’s parents couldn’t tell her much about her biological family.

All they had been told was that Stacey’s biological parents had been young when she was born and couldn’t look after a baby.

They are adamant that another biological sibling was never mentioned by the adoption agency.

If they had been told about another sibling, Stacey’s parents definitely would have adopted both of them.

"It was in our DNA"

Instead, Stacey grew up into an awkward teenager, feeling like an outsider in her adopted family, unable to stop comparing herself to her adoptive parents’ biological kids.

Her self-esteem was so poor that when a cute boy named *Tyler asked her on a date – Stacey couldn’t work out why he would want to spend time with her.

But in the end, she said yes anyway.

The pair went on a date to a local burger restaurant and were amused to discover that they had the exact same favourite order – a well-done bison burger with no onions and no pickles.

“I thought it was pretty dang cool,” Stacey said.

“But I now know it had less to do with ‘cuteness,’ and more to do with our DNA.”

Adoption advocate calls to cut red tape 465984 There are currently 50,000 Australian children living in foster care and their chance of being adopted is less than one per cent. To mark National Adoption Awareness Month, Adopt Change CEO Renee Carter is calling for red tape to be cut so children can be more easily placed in a permanent home. Ms Carter says the foster care system can be ‘really damaging’ for children, with some moving up to 70 times, ‘so really it’s just not good enough’.

"Stacey’s parents couldn’t tell her much about her biological family." Source: iStock

It only brought them closer

It would be months before Stacey and Tyler would learn the truth.

In the meantime, the pair started dating, spending more and more time together.

About four months into their relationship, the couple realised that they had both been adopted and had no contact with their biological parents.

At the time, no alarm bells went off in Stacey’s mind.

Instead, she was just relieved that Tyler could really understand her painful journey as an adopted kid.

It only brought them closer together.

The Christmas present that changed everything

By the time their first Christmas came around, Stacey and Tyler had said 'I love you' and were planning their lives together.

For months they had been talking about taking DNA tests to learn more about their biological families.

The only problem was the hefty price tag for each test.

Stacey thought it would be romantic to save up for two tests as Christmas presents for her and Tyler.

Tyler loved the gift and together they sent in the tests, excited to finally get to know their biological families.

"We had no idea!"

But as Stacey would soon learn, this would actually end up being more confusing.

Struggling to piece together her family tree, Stacey went to see a ‘DNA search angel’ to help her fill in the blanks.

It was there that she discovered that she and Tyler were actually siblings who had been separated at birth.

“Imagine having your boyfriend who you LOVED come to visit you at your house and having to break the news that 'hey, I might be your sister. Actually, I am your sister. 100 percent',” Stacey said.

“'Yeah, you know those awful bio parents of ours that totally kicked us to the curb and ditched us? They’re actually the same ones'.

“I remember him staring blankly at me, ‘what do you mean we’re siblings??!!?!?!’

“We had been dating for several months at that point. We had no idea! It’s a unique trauma.”

"We’re better together"

It’s now been a year since Stacey and Tyler discovered the truth about their heritage.

Obviously, the revelation has been tough on both of them – after all, as Stacey said, there aren’t exactly support groups for ‘accidental incest’.

They are both still in counselling and took a two-month break from speaking to each other.

“But through it all, we’ve decided to still love each other, just in a different way now,” Stacey said.

“Like I said, it’s a unique trauma, but no one knows it better than we do.

“We went from strangers to lovers, to sister and brother, to strangers to great friends.

“I’m glad we are still there for each other. We’re better together.”

*Names have been changed
